intro: Angelica sylvestris proles ceretanica, commonly known as the lesser angelica or wild angelica, is a biennial or short-lived perennial herb native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots, parsley, and celery, and is characterized by its tall, hollow stems and large, compound leaves. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers in umbels, typical of the Apiaceae family, and is often found in moist meadows and woodland edges. Its roots and leaves are used in traditional medicine and culinary applications, though it is considered toxic in large quantities.
